title: 110_s3571
content: The "Health Impact Assessments Act of 2008" or the "HIA Act of 2008" requires studies by the Government Accountability Office to identify best practices for assessing the planning and impact of land use, building design, and social policy on community health. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study on best practices for using health impact assessments to promote health and reduce disparities in public policies. This study will also review the health consequences of Federal policies and programs. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study on the negative health consequences of Federal policies and programs, and how to consider health impact assessments for projects involving Federal funding or work. A report will be submitted to Congress within 1 year describing the study results. The National Demonstration Program is outlined in Section 3. The Secretary will award a grant to an institution of higher education to provide technical assistance, grants, and training on health impact assessments for community planning and policy making. This includes collecting data, disseminating best practices, and administering a demonstration grant program. The Center awarded a grant for consultation with national organizations on health impact assessments. A demonstration program will award grants to eligible entities for designing and administering health impact assessments. Eligible entities include state and local government departments. Collaboration among state and local entities is required for those receiving grants. Authorization of appropriations for carrying out activities under the grant includes $1,000,000 for fiscal year 2009 for subsection (a) and such sums as necessary for fiscal years 2010 through 2013. For subsection (b), $4,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2009 and such sums as necessary for fiscal years 2010 and 2011. Collaboration among eligible entities is required for grant activities. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention will expand activities to improve public health and reduce disparities by assessing health impacts of land use, housing, transportation policies, and social decisions. $1,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2009, with additional funding for 2010-2013. The Act defines "built environment" as all buildings, spaces, and products created or modified by individuals, including homes, schools, workplaces, parks, transportation systems, and waste disposal sites. It also defines "health impact assessment" as analyzing the effects of policies, programs, or projects on population health and identifying actions to manage those effects. The Secretary of Health and Human Services can evaluate health effects of projects and policies, providing recommendations for improved outcomes through collaboration and transparency in policy making.
